content.description: Spectrum looks innocent enough, but it's tricky enough that you might be questioning the rating by the time you top out. Starts as a right-facing corner, but turns into more of a slot after surpassing a small roof 15 or 20 feet off the ground. Fixed anchor at the top.
content.location: This is the bottom to top crack system located sort of left-central on Lost Bandana Wall.

content.description: A fun climb with three distinct sections.  A left facing offwidth that starts wide and narrows to #4 at the top, (turn right) onto a low angle slab layback following the R side of a roof, and the second pitch of “limbo”; a left facing dihedral from #4 to #2.  Can be broken into two pitches to avoid some rope drag.
content.protection: Singles of BD .4-#1, Doubles of BD#2-#4.  Two sets of bolted anchors are located on top of the low angle slab, before the left facing dihedral at the top.  You’ll need at least 30-40 feet of cord or rope if you want to set up a TR below the LFD.
content.location: Located on the left end of the Lost Bandana Wall

content.description: Work up left leaning seam and crack.
content.location: Starts on the right side of Lost Bandana Wall. To the right of Loosy Loose.

climbs.name: Owl Out
climbs.fa: Glen Dickinson and Cindy Zarlengo in 1981

content.description: Left leaning crack. Fun climb with some jammin' and jugs and good foot work.
content.protection: Two bolt anchor located to climbers left of finish.  Single rack from .5 to #3 plus a set of nuts.
content.location: Starts in a gully behind Seemingly Useless towards the east side.

content.description: Face climb thin sharp crimps to more thin sharp crimps. After the bulges the grade eases. A few tough clipping stances with ledge fall potential.   With more traffic, this route could be rid of of the thin hollow crystal filled flakes that both make it possible and make it interesting especially when they snap, crackle, and pop.
content.location: To the right of Lawless and Free. Rap down.

content.description:
Pitch 1) Limbo starts on the left end of Lost Bandana Wall in a short corner system. Climb the corner (pro), then onto the face up and right to a bolt. Pass two more bolts climbing up the face to a large ledge above. There's a crack in the back that you can set a gear anchor (might be bolts now). If you only do this pitch, you can either walk off the right end of the wall (careful!) or rappel off one of the fixed anchor setups.

 Pitch 2) Around to the left is a short, but nice dihedral. You might have to move your belay. Climb the corner to the top. Walk off.
content.protection: single #2 or #3 cam and 3 bolts.  2 bolt anchor.
content.location: Right of Slot Style but left of Spectrum & or Lawless.

content.description: LAWless and Free is a great face route with nice edges and crystals. Starting just right of the classic Spectrum crack, climb up and right to the fairly high first bolt (be careful!), then continue up and over some bulges and scoops past two more bolts to the top. Excellent!`
content.protection: Three bolts. Bolted anchor at the top (if it's not there, you can take some gear in the medium size range to set an anchor).
content.location: Lost Bandana Wall, more or less in the middle, located just right of the straight-up crack that forms Spectrum.

content.description: Thin start to a slabby upper portion that ends at the top block's left most corner.
content.location: Thin face left of the Spectrum crack.

climbs.name: Family Affair
climbs.fa: Steve Smelser, Sherry DUncan, Jason Sandidge 1987

content.description: Good beginner climb. Great place to learn smearing. Some good holds. Don't expect much on the granite.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location: This is a face next to Owl Out. Head east from Seemingly Useless.

content.description:
Lost Bandana Wall is probably the most popular spot at Little Granite Mountain for climbing (of course this is all relative). Easily accessible and with a number of routes, it is a favorite for groups to come and spend the day. The southern exposure makes it a good winter spot, but conversely turns it into an oven in early fall and late spring.

 You can scramble to the top of the wall (or off the wall) via it's right (east) end with a short bit of 4th class climbing.
